title: Union Territories (Part VIII of the Indian Constitution)

information.title: Definition
information.description: Union Territories (UTs) are administrative divisions directly governed by the Central Government of India. They are mentioned in Part VIII of the Constitution.

information.title: Administration
information.description: UTs are administered by the President through an appointed administrator. The President can specify the designation of the administrator, who usually holds the title of Lieutenant Governor or Administrator.

information.title: Parliament's Power
information.description: According to Article 239A, Parliament may create a legislature and Council of Ministers for certain UTs. Currently, Delhi, Puducherry, and Jammu & Kashmir have their own legislatures.

information.title: Current Union Territories
information.description: As of 2023, India has 8 Union Territories: Andaman and Nicobar Islands, Chandigarh, Dadra and Nagar Haveli and Daman and Diu, Delhi, Jammu and Kashmir, Ladakh, Lakshadweep, and Puducherry.

information.title: Special Provisions
information.description: Some UTs like Delhi and Puducherry have special provisions. For instance, Delhi, as the National Capital Territory, has a unique status with its own elected government but limited powers.

information.title: Creation and Changes
information.description: New UTs can be created or existing ones can be changed through an act of Parliament. For example, in 2019, Jammu and Kashmir was reorganized into two UTs: Jammu and Kashmir, and Ladakh.
